text: full review on IT FOLLOWS: I am very harsh on horror movies because i am sick of the same old crap. I can truly say that I enjoyed and loved "it follows" it was original, fun and horrifying in its own way. It relied on what every horror movie should rely on. Fear. I saw maybe about 2 scenes with blood and that was only little bits of blood on them. It pulled off good horror without blood because good horror movies should not rely on blood. It doesnt deliver a scare. It follows also wasnt too predictable. Some parts were. But for the most part I was not sure how the ending played out. It did play out very nicely. About a little before halfway through the movie i started to think i was gonna be extremely disappointed after anticipating it for so long, but I didn't. I loved the cinematography, I loved the plot, I loved the horror, I enjoyed especially how much character development they did. They actually built up their characters which is respectable and amazing and something I truly look for in a horror movie. The characters were also relatable and not too dumb. One or two scenes you can easily say "Are you stupid?" but for the most part they stay pretty smart about it. I truly also thought the ending was phenomenal. Will not spoil it, but it was chilling. Above all I enjoyed how they put the characters having real conversations and carried on things that didnt sound too scripted. They kept it natural and didnt over exaggerate on the situation, not did they not care at all. The writing was such a high point. Another one of the highpoints is the soundtrack. I loved the music in this. It reminded me of an old horror film. The only real problems i can think of is there are a few awkward crossfades in the editing and there were a couple actors that just didnt seem to care. It seemed scripted for maybe one or two characters. overall i give "It follows" a 9.5/10 smile emoticon

text: I hate how underestimated this movie is by a lot of people. There's a reason why Rotten Tomatoes gave it a 96%, ladies and gentlemen.   First of all, this movie has the creepiest soundtrack I have ever heard in my entire life. I'm not joking, this soundtrack is like what you can only hear if you're living in the 90s. Extremely spine-chilling if you're at the theater.   Second of all, this movie has obvious educative messages and HIV/AIDS awareness undertones. The characters must have sex in order to rid themselves off the curse, but they'll pass it on to someone else and feel guilty about it. It's like the reality: teens having unprotected sex and getting STDs and transferring them to next partner.. Even more terrifying that being haunted. Aside from that, did you notice the scene in which Jay sits in class and the teacher reads one of T.S.Elliot's works: "The Love Song of J.Alfred Prufrock?" And that scene when Yara reads two passages from Fyodor Dostoevsky's "The Idiot"? Those passages are about the imminence of death and how people fail at postponing their end.   Third of all, the antagonist of the movie. "It." It is not a human, it is a malicious entity that apparently just kills. Oh, shape-shifting is its hobby too. So the point here is, the entity isn't a gruesome, hideous devil. IT is just the embodiment of our fear. IT is always two steps behind us, watching us, waiting to catch up... Ever had a feeling of being followed? That's what IT is all about. The antagonist plans to strike in that same fear of yours and maximize it. We are afraid of it, so we run, but it follows, and it never stops, like how our fear will hardly ever leave us.   That's your part, but as for Jay, well, she's gonna suffer forever. IT just keeps following you and you just have to keep running, but it will catch up to you and then you'll die. Even if you pass it on, the other victims won't survive forever, and it will come back to you, and you'll have to keep doing it over and over again. And you'll still end up dead.   => So what's this movie about? Much like Oculus and The Babadook (brilliant things,) it tries to strike into your fear. Imagine, you wake up in the morning, gaze out the window and find a stranger staring unblinkingly at you, always trying to come closer until it can stand next to your bed and watch you sleep. You can't trust anyone, because it can be everyone. Hear knocks on the door? Maybe it's IT, maybe it's not. You can't be sure. Hear strange sounds around the house at night? What if that's IT walking to you? You are never safe. Always watched, always followed, always vulnerable to death. Pass it on, and you still see it. It will come back one day. You'll never be at peace.   Let that soak in.

text: Please, do not buy into IMDB or these comments. I have no idea what people are smoking, but if you want a horror film - this isn't it. It's not even a thriller. You want story? Doesn't have it. STD is as far as you'll guess. You want action? Go watch some specialized horror, because the only horror here is the sudden and completely unreasonable transformation and the sucked up impression that something bad is about to happen... but it never really does. You want jump scares? Oh, them you'll get here. That's probably as far as this movie could deliver. Seriously, the locking inside of the room and the ball to the window are probably the only two "scary" moments in the movie, and all because of the jump effect. You want reason? Not happening. "It" will be toyed with like some Alien. It has super strength, it is afraid of doorknobs, it is susceptible physically, it "respawns".  Now, certainly, if you want a cheap, I repeat - CHEAP horror to watch in the afternoon, most likely intoxicated and not really giving a flying fuck - by all means, enjoy. And that is not an offense towards you or the movie - just a plausible suggestion. It's indie and it's simple. It might deliver some shivers, some unease, but by the end of it you'll just wonder - what the fuck was it all for. The cliffhanger will totally ruin anything this movie tried to build up. So it's not the worst possible horror, not worse than some Leprechaun. But it by no means is a breakthrough or genius or any sort of impressive in the genre. IT IS NOT ANYTHING ABOVE 6\10. 4-6\10 - that's the rating bracket for the movie.

text: It's kind of sad how many people didn't get this movie.  If you're comparing it to ' A Cabin In The Woods'  ( which is a horrible comparison) it's a pretty clear indication you failed to understand what ' It Follows' is about.  ' A Cabin In The Woods' is a movie where everything happens on the screen. You don't have to imagine or think at all. Everything is shoved up your ass making it impossible for you to miss a single thing.   ' It Follows' happens mostly in your head. It engages your imagination and toys with your brain, rendering you completely paranoid over what, where or who 'It' is.   If you didn't get it, it's because nothing happened in your head as you were watching.  Your brain didn't pick up on the clues the film-maker put in there, because it has been taught to react only to the ' In Your Face-scares'  movies like ' ACITW ' spoiled it with. Because of this, you sat there bored while you missed a piece of truly great and unique piece of entertainment.   It's actually very sad.  I pity you.

text: I've heard a lot of theories about this movie and what the demon is supposed to be... none of them really make sense though. I'm pretty sure that at face value it simply is what it appears to be, a sexually transmitted demon that is invisible to others but can interact with our world and other people. If we are going to delve deeper into analogy though, I feel like a good case could be made that the demon represents death, as it slowly follows you throughout life. You're aware it's there and you spend your entire life running from it, but you know that eventually it will catch up to you. The poem that the girl with glasses reads at the end is reflective of this. One can go even further and point out that what is happening to the protagonist is a type of existential anxiety and depression. Others around her don't seem to see the same 'demon' she can, because they are oblivious to it. I feel that the way everyone else in the movie including the mother, police officer, nurses and teachers are portrayed as very distant and inconsequential to the plot represents how people with depression/major anxiety feel isolated from everyone around them. Only the protagonist and her friends seem to be affected by it, and each of her friends are dismissive of her problem to different degree's. The mother is especially interesting; we typically see her drinking or chatting with her friends about her daughter but we never really see her talk to her. I know it's not a perfect analogy, but I find looking at this movie thru that lens makes it very interesting, and the unfeeling, heartless and seemingly purposeless path of destruction the demon slowly inflicts on it's victims is very much like death.
